title.narrative: Green Economy: Sustainable Mountain Tourism and Organic Agriculture (GRETA)
Green Economy: Sustainable Mountain Tourism and Organic Agriculture (GRETA)

description.narrative: The objective of the intervention is to facilitate an improvement of the business environment and the creation of new income opportunities in sustainable mountain tourism and organic agriculture in order to reduce poverty and exclusion in the selected mountain areas of Georgia.

Austrian Development Agency (ADA) has applied to Embassy for funding of SEK 30 500 000 to carry out the intervention "Green Economy: Sustainable Mountain Tourism and Organic Agriculture (GRETA)". The intervention is part of the EU framework of the Annual Action Programme 2017 for the Republic of Georgia: Action Document for Economic and Business Development in Georgia under the European Neighborhood Instrument (ENI). The Action Programme's overall objective is to foster socio-economic development in Georgia and has three inter-related thematic components: 1) Fairer and faster litigation in commercial matters, 2) Modernized financial infrastructure and 3) Greater business sophistication. The latter component includes the delegated action from the European Union to ADA, for which the Embassy has been approached to provide complementary Swedish funding.
The proposed intervention aims at facilitating an improvement of the business environment and the creation of new income opportunities in sustainable mountain tourism and organic agriculture to reduce poverty and exclusion in selected regions of Georgia. The duration of the intervention is 52 months (2018-2023), starting with an 8-month inception phase. The total budget of the proposed intervention, including EU and ADA co-financing, is approximately SEK 70 000 000.
Georgia's high mountainous regions already attract an increasing number of tourists and makes some use of its suitable conditions for organic agriculture production, but has a large potential of growth and development. Simultaneously, the mountainous regions are among Georgia's poorest, and the populations' perception of limited employment and income generation opportunities cause high rates of migration from the villages. The intervention is intended to realize the potential of high mountainous areas to contribute to SME development, organic agricultural production, employment and poverty reduction, increased income, while responding to Georgia's increasing number of tourists in these areas, as well as increasing product and service demands.
The activities of the intervention include facilitation of a Mountainous Tourism Development Strategy, including, Destination Management and Branding Policy, establishment of a national quality standard and control system for local tourism suppliers, stimulation of innovation and creation of new market linkages. Access and provision of capacity development measures for people and institutions, which are active in the fields of sustainable mountain tourism and organic agriculture in the target regions are integral parts of the intervention. The latter will enable joint learning among public, private and civil society actors. The environment and social sustainability, as well as the gender equality is expected to be further strengthened, based on the results of environmental, gender and social impact assessment to be conducted during inception stage of the intervention, which will affect the design of the activities.
Overall, through promoting sustainable development in tourism and organic agriculture sectors, the intervention is expected to contribute to increased employment and income opportunities in the target regions.

Österrikes biståndsorganisation, Austrian Development Agency (ADA), har ansökt om finansiering om 30 500 000 kronor i syfte att genomföra insatsen "Grön ekonomi: Hållbar bergsturism och ekologiskt jordbruk (GRETA)". Insatsen ingår inom ramen för EU:s årliga handlingsprogram 2017 för republiken Georgien: Handlingsdokument för ekonomisk och affärsutveckling i Georgien inom ramen för det Europeiska Grannskapsinstrumentet (ENI). Programmets övergripande mål är att främja socioekonomisk utveckling i Georgien och har tre sammanhängande tematiska komponenter: 1) Rättvisare och snabbare rättstvister i kommersiella frågor, 2) Moderniserad finansiell infrastruktur och 3) Effektiviserad företagsamhet. Den senare komponenten inkluderar en delegerad insats från Europeiska unionen till ADA, för vilken ambassaden har kontaktats för att bidra med kompletterande svensk finansiering.
Den föreslagna insatsen syftar till att underlätta förbättring av företagsamheten och skapandet av nya inkomstmöjligheter inom hållbar bergsturism och ekologiskt jordbruk för att minska fattigdom och utanförskap i utvalda regioner i Georgien. Insatsens varaktighet är 52 månader (2018–2023), inklusive en åtta månaders inledningsfas. Den totala budgeten för den föreslagna insatsen, inklusive samfinansiering från EU och ADA, är cirka 70 000 000 SEK.
Georgiens höga bergsområden lockar redan ett ökande antal turister och landet utnyttjar sina förutsättningar för ekologisk jordbruksproduktion i viss mån, men har stor tillväxt- och utvecklingspotential. Bergsområdena är bland Georgiens fattigaste regioner och invånarnas uppfattning om begränsade sysselsättnings- och inkomstgenererande möjligheter orsakar stor utflyttning från byarna. Insatsen syftar till att realisera potentialen i de höga bergsområdena för att bidra till utveckling av små och medelstora företag, ekologisk jordbruksproduktion, sysselsättning och fattigdomsminskning, ökade inkomster, och samtidigt svara upp mot Georgiens växande turism i dessa områden, liksom ökad efterfrågan på varor och tjänster.
Aktiviteterna i insatsen inkluderar framtagande av en strategi för utveckling av bergsturism, inklusive så kallad destinationsledning (Destination Management) och varumärkespolicy, etablering av nationell kvalitetsstandard och kontrollsystem för lokala leverantörer inom turism, stimulering av innovation och skapande av nya marknadskontakter. Tillhandahållande av kapacitetsutvecklingsstöd för individer och institutioner som är aktiva inom hållbar bergsturism och ekologiskt jordbruk i regionerna, utgör en väsentlig del av insatsen. Detta kommer att möjliggöra gemensamt lärande bland offentliga, privata och civila samhällsaktörer. Miljömässig och social hållbarhet samt jämställdhet förväntas stärkas ytterligare baserat på resultaten av den miljö-, jämställdhets- och sociala konsekvensbedömningen, som ska genomföras under inledningsfasen av insatsen, vilka kommer att påverka utformningen av aktiviteterna.
Sammantaget förväntas insatsen genom att främja en hållbar utveckling inom turism och ekologisk jordbruksproduktion bidra till ökade sysselsättnings- och inkomstmöjligheter i de aktuella regionerna.

Reproductive, Maternal, Newborn and Child Health (RMNCH)

description.narrative: 2020 was the 2nd year of the implementation GRETA project and COVID 19 has had a huge impact on its progress. While two major components of the GRETA project, Sustainable Mountain Tourism (SMT) and Organic Agriculture (OA), are progressing at various stages the SMT is more behind the schedule, due to the fact that COVID 19 is having greater impact on the tourism sector in general, as well as travel and meeting restrictions, and the key stakeholders working in emergency mode. In Georgia, the number of international travellers declined by more than 90% in December 2020 compared to the same period of 2019, same was for the number of international visitors, which also fell by 90%. During the year, the three co donors of GRETA, Sweden/EU/Austria have been in active communication with the GRETA team to stay updated on the challenges and delays caused during COVID 19 and it is to be noted, that overall, the GRETA project strived to be flexible and made significant adjustments for the planning and implementation. Based on the 2020 annual reporting, following are the examples of the expected and unexpected results under the SMT component: - During the reporting period, the GRETA project managed to announce Tourism Development Initiative 2020 (TDI) grant scheme. The impact of COVID-19 on the tourism sector, causing it to come to a complete halt, was clearly visible in the significant number of applications for the TDI 2020 grant scheme, which was publicized in July 2020. The total number of applications (1261) far exceeded what the project had planned for - Destination Management Office (DMO) Svaneti has been established and strengthened, the GRETA project has progressed well with the development of the Svaneti Branding project. The DMO business cluster development has started with the Svaneti Destination Branding. This creational process brings together various stakeholders from all three sectors: public, private and civil. The creation of the DMO website has been initiated. Despite travel restrictions, an Austrian consultancy company was able to start their initial analysis and are in the process of reporting on DMO operational needs, potential revenue and best practices based on European standards, what capacity building initiatives would be best applicable in Georgia and overall recommendations for sustainable DMO systems in Georgia - Trainings in hiking took place during the reporting period and will continue during the summer of 2021. Trainings of trail marking/maintenance have been contracted. Guesthouse trainings were conducted partially in face-to-face mode and partially in online mode by ELKANA and were very well received by the beneficiaries, with clear message from them to have more and in-depth trainings in the future Despite the COVID-19 crisis, OA component has steadily progressed. The major expected and unexpected results under the OA component are as follows: - GRETA project provided a high-quality translated document of the new EU organic regulations. Furthermore, the facilitation of the proper harmonization of the new EU organic regulations is progressing and the Ministry of Environment Protection and Agriculture of Georgia (MEPA) has proceeded to introduce the new Georgian Organic Legislation - A Market and Feasibility Study for identification of the most promising value chains has been conducted and the opportunities for additional initiation have been identified. Therefore, based on the study outcomes and the experience gained through the project implementation period, project team initiated and conducted the additional research (Pesticide-Free). As of now, the research report has been submitted to GRETA and is in the revision process - 14 project beneficiaries (3 female/11 male) have been identified, trained and equipment procurement process has started for strenghtening of the local farmers/producer groups in conversion to organic agriculture - Project beneficiaries participated in the international fair Agro Export Forum 2020 (online). Before COVID-19, project had planned?6?organic open markets, which were postponed.?Next steps depend on restrictions introduced/lifted by?GoG - 7 employees (1 female/ 6 male) of local certification agencies (including 4 inspectors) have been trained in EU regulations and organic certification practices; Due to the high interest from local certification agencies, the target has been exceeded, since instead of 2 staff members, 7 were trained not only in EU regulations and certifications but also in aquaculture certification - 8 extension agents (5 females / 3 males) and field experts have been trained in organic agriculture and certification practices; it’s essential for further training modules to have a face-to-face format. In case COVID-19 restrictions are prolonged, it might become challenging to reach the target - To improve the access of advisory services in organic agriculture for the local producers, 3 leader farmers/processors have been identified Communication and visibility Throughout the reporting period the project has been actively updating communication and A&B (Activity and Beneficiaries) sections in the EUDigitool, (separately providing information to Sweden and Austria through the email correspondence) and has been sustaining constant coordination with EU4Georgia - the technical assistance communication project for the EU delegation to Georgia. The project follows agreed communication approach implies customised (target group-specific) communication techniques, aiming to establish long-term close relationships with target groups and maintaining a constant mutual exchange of information. The COVID-19 and its global economic and political implications have influenced the GRETA project operation as well as the communication component. However, the project managed to adjust its working approach. All project activities are being implemented according to the ADA rules and guidelines for emergency situations, while announcements and communication with beneficiaries have been adapted to a more “COVID-19 sensitive style”, with more online and distance communication, e.g., digital communication, sending SMSs and telemarketing. All the component managers remain reachable to provide any follow-up communication and consultations. In addition, the project has set up a landline to be more accessible for target groups. Besides, the GRETA project’s visibility guidelines are incorporated in every activity that the project implements.
No indicator available - only a description of the activity results is published
